title: 113_hr2818
content: The "Surveillance State Repeal Act" aims to repeal the USA PATRIOT Act and the FISA Amendments Act of 2008, restoring the provisions of law as if these acts had not been enacted. Additionally, it addresses the terms of judges on the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court, reappointment, and special masters. The Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978 is amended to increase the maximum term for judges to ten years and allows for reappointment. Special Masters with technological expertise can be appointed to advise courts on technical issues during proceedings. The Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978 is amended to allow electronic surveillance of specified persons without regard to specific devices. It also includes provisions for collecting information under the Act. The Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978 is further amended to include a warrant requirement for acquiring information related to a United States person. Additionally, there are amendments to the table of contents to reflect these changes. The Act also addresses encryption and privacy technology of electronic devices and software. SEC. 7 prohibits the Federal Government from mandating manufacturers to build mechanisms allowing bypassing encryption or privacy technology in electronic devices or software. SEC. 8 requires annual compliance evaluations with the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act. SEC. 9 addresses whistleblower complaints. Employees or contractors in the intelligence community can report complaints about programs authorized by the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act to various entities. The Comptroller General will investigate these complaints and submit a report to Congress. Employees or contractors in the intelligence community can report complaints about programs authorized by the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act. A "covered complaint" refers to evidence of a violation of law, gross mismanagement, waste of funds, abuse of authority, or danger to public health or safety. SEC. 10. PROHIBITION ON INTERFERENCE WITH REPORTING OF WASTE, FRAUD, ABUSE, OR CRIMINAL BEHAVIOR. (a) An officer or employee of the intelligence community can face administrative sanctions, including termination, for retaliating against an employee or contractor who discloses covered information to specified entities. Covered information includes evidence of wrongdoing. The term "covered information" refers to evidence of violations of laws, rules, or regulations, mismanagement, waste of funds, abuse of authority, or dangers to public health or safety. The term "intelligence community" is defined in the National Security Act of 1947.
